body: I'm referring to myself, who has no talent whatsoever in any area. Even in my areas of biggest interest that I've been doing for years, beginners easily crush me. Everyone I know does what I think is impossible in extremely short times with no sweat. I'm smart, but I have no natural abilities at all, I'm just not wired for anything I like at a fundamental level. I'm forever damned to scramble for a 2 or 3 in everything while others easily get a 10 in at least one thing, usually most or even all of them. And it's true, "work harder" only gets me from a 1 to a 3 or 4, while the others go from 5 to 10.

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

body:
Being smart is an ability dude. Have you ever considered that it's a perception issue you have in yourself, especially by comparison? There is a good chance you are locking yourself out of potential stuffs you are good at because of your hesitance.

I had no direction for the stupid shit I think, do and say until someone suggested singing in a band and I found I have a knack for music and entertainment in general because I have empathy, a sense of humour overpronounced feelings, good timing and high literacy. All of those things stem from my own anxiety and the coping mechanisms I subconsciously developed.

Do you define things as successful only if a living can be made from it, or you are able to guage progress against others?
body_html:
Being smart is an ability dude. Have you ever considered that it's a perception issue you have in yourself, especially by comparison? There is a good chance you are locking yourself out of potential stuffs you are good at because of your hesitance.

I had no direction for the stupid shit I think, do and say until someone suggested singing in a band and I found I have a knack for music and entertainment in general because I have empathy, a sense of humour overpronounced feelings, good timing and high literacy. All of those things stem from my own anxiety and the coping mechanisms I subconsciously developed.

Do you define things as successful only if a living can be made from it, or you are able to guage progress against others?

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
> There is a good chance you are locking yourself out of potential stuffs you are good at because of your hesitance.

I'm not hesitant at anything. I've tried everything that interests me. I've been doing them for years before I even realized this. I'm only "good" at them in the sense that I can copy others and impress those who never even tried. But when it comes to reality I can never amount to anything, and I've denied it for too long and it never did me any good.

Can I make a shitty half-baked attempt in 200x the time it takes someone else to produce an utterly *flawless* result? Yes, but that's not really worth it. There are gods in this world, don't lie to me we've all seen it, and then there are normal people, and then there are those for whom everything goes wrong.

If you don't believe me:

[I'm a programmer](https://github.com/CrystalVulpine) but even with way more time I'll never match what these guys just do naturally:

https://github.com/foxite

https://github.com/gingkathfox

https://github.com/lithiumjs

None of my ruqqus or reddit communities have been successful, but people like stars_in_blue_major and no_chill and AddictedReddit have a damn near 100% success rate.

This person both learned 5 languages fluently and several others decently in only a year and is also really good at drawing: https://www.reddit.com/user/frummerfuchs/

I enjoy wittiness and humor but can't do it myself, yet many others can. I'm also not very creative at all, even though that's exactly what I like doing. Before I went through puberty this wasn't the case, and it seems to have affected most guys.

Some people know every corner of the internet and my only resource is still google so I can never find anything.

I like making posts but I can never find any content that's not already famous and when I do I take an hour coming up with the blandest titles. Check +foxes, my own guild, where the other posters have no issues with this.

I like learning and reading a lot but I just don't know anything still. Even in my biggest field of interest the other people are talking gibberish terms to me. From my perspective it feels like they're omniscient and just know everything about everything automatically.

[And don't even get me started on sfrohne/cqtz](https://ruqqus.com/+uslashremoved/post/695h/sfrohne-permanently-banned-for-linking-to/lwd4)

At this point all my efforts have been vain and I don't see any denying that I just got unlucky genes and my lot in life is to be a miserable medicore little shit forever. Even happiness has been proven to be mostly *determined* by your genes. I tried to deny it for years but it just didn't work.

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body: Says the talent savant. I don't think most people blessed with a tons of gifts understand that some people simply don't have it in them, as they've never experienced real, permanent failure, only the bumps on the road to success. No matter how hard you try, if your brain is fundamentally not wired for something you're not going to be able to do it. It may be possible to succeed with determination in movies but in real life talent plays a much bigger role than our egalitarian minds like to admit. In fact I think it is *the* biggest determining factor (and science backs up my observation). Practice always makes you improve but in reality it's only a marginal difference, the biggest factor is indeed how much natural talent you were lucky enough to inherit. Fortunately most people are drawn to what they're good at, and if that's nothing they're content to just sit back and hang around and passively enjoy life. I definitely inherited that, but unfortunately something went wrong for me and I'm desiring to do the exact opposite of what I was primed for.

No matter how hard you try, if your brain is fundamentally not wired for something you're not going to be able to do it. It may be possible to succeed with determination in movies but in real life talent plays a much bigger role than our egalitarian minds like to admit. In fact I think it is the biggest determining factor (and science backs up my observation). Practice always makes you improve but in reality it's only a marginal difference, the biggest factor is indeed how much natural talent you were lucky enough to inherit. Fortunately most people are drawn to what they're good at, and if that's nothing they're content to just sit back and hang around and passively enjoy life. I definitely inherited that, but unfortunately something went wrong for me and I'm desiring to do the exact opposite of what I was primed for.

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

body:
I don't even really think most of my "talents" were innate. I just followed what I found enjoyable and pursued them.

Hell, my "art talent" is really just one monolith of a decade's worth of failures and missteps, i even doubted myself so many times in the past and even still do today. 

I think the point im trying to make is that failure or mistakes aren't reason alone to admit defeat. They're lessons. and well... without failure, we know not where we need to improve or have reason to change.

And that's something i don't exactly make any money on, as I do not create for others for money at this time.

And that's something i don't exactly make any money on, as I do not create for others for money at this time.

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body: I've done things for 10 years too, and I still suck at them. Of course you weren't as good at first, but it's overall still way better. Skill ceilings do exist, and at some point you just can't get any better, or if you do it's extremely marginal. And that maxed-out level is different for everyone, and that's what talent is. If your brain is not wired to be able to do something, you will never be able to do it right. It's like having the wrong tools for a job.
body_html: I've done things for 10 years too, and I still suck at them. Of course you weren't as good at first, but it's overall still way better. Skill ceilings do exist, and at some point you just can't get any better, or if you do it's extremely marginal. And that maxed-out level is different for everyone, and that's what talent is. If your brain is not wired to be able to do something, you will never be able to do it right. It's like having the wrong tools for a job.

I don't even really think most of my "talents" were innate. I just followed what I found enjoyable and pursued them.

Hell, my "art talent" is really just one monolith of a decade's worth of failures and missteps, i even doubted myself so many times in the past and even still do today.

I think the point im trying to make is that failure or mistakes aren't reason alone to admit defeat. They're lessons. and well... without failure, we know not where we need to improve or have reason to change.

And that's something i don't exactly make any money on, as I do not create for others for money at this time.

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

body:
Doesn't sound like you've been taking the right drugs. But no worries, put that aside.

I know its goofy, but have you considered any spiritual practices? Shamanic practices might seem goofy and stupid, but genuine and competent practicioners have a natural talent (plus training) for understanding and accurately interpreting brain waves and the different states they invoke, as well as a knack for practical methods in how to control and alter these states. Here is a link for some info about what activities your brain is primed for in different brainwave frequencies if you aren't familiar:

https://brainworksneurotherapy.com/what-are-brainwaves

I only suggest shamanic practices (ceremonial and ritual type medicines; drumming and other percussion, dancing, chanting, humming etc) because I have had success with methods like that. But there are more modern approaches which I started off using (psychiatry, technology based interpretations of your different stages, EEG's, fMRI's and using pharmacuetical medicines, digital tones, lights, images etc to alter and control states). I went modern to gain a foundational understanding that made logical sense to me, then moved onto a fusion of traditional and modern practices. Give it some consideration if you have no experience.

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

body: You just seem like you need to unlock your brain. Whether to find a way around your percieved metiocrity, or just cope with the perception. You'd probably be surprised at how ritualistic you already are. Especialy if you are a programmer. Rituals are just clearly defined acknowledgment of your own intergrated processes. Once you start defining your different internal processes they start to take a different form, one you can begin to control. It's all hippy sounding junk, but it works, and science is beginning to support it now that neural pathways, connections, activities and the roles they play are becoming better understood. Like I said; just consider it!

post.title: Talent vs Skill: There’s a clear winner. | The Power of Talent

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
Is it dumb and full of shit or a harsh truth that makes you angry? A lot of people tend to knee-jerk denounce something if it's uncomfortable for them. However it has been my experience that talented people can be lazy and get to an insane level, while others work their tail off for years and still get mediocre results. Do you deny the existence of people with retardation disorders? Can you seriously expect an ant to become as smart as a person by sheer will? No you can't. Nurture helps but it still depends on nature. It makes perfect sense biologically, everyone serves a different task in a tribe or society and is optimized for that role. The problem is, this is outdated now. Less than 200 years ago, you carried on your family legacy because that's what you were good at, whether you liked it or not. Some families farmed, because that's what they were good at. Some families entered trades they were good at. Others ran business or became politicians and lawyers, because they were good at that. Men did physical labor and fighting, or less often leading, because that's what they were good at. Women did intellectual and creative things, and raised children, because that's what they were good at. People are social animals, and you are optimized to serve your tribe above all else. So each person is specialized for certain tasks, and other functions are nerfed because they get in the way of the role they're suppose to do. They are also hierarchical by nature, so some will naturally be at the top and capable of more things, while the commoners are more limited and simple. Now we have more time to ourselves to explore passions, but our brains are still hardwired by survival instincts to say "no" and prep us for a specialized function to benefit the tribe. So those who inherited from the elites or those matching their interests have no issues, but those who didn't are forever stuck battling against how they're wired at a fundamental level.

Take me for example. I am a young male whose family has a history of being simple people, mostly farmers and stereotypical workers. And that's fine. But I inherited the optimization for that, and go figure, I am into creating things, programming, storytelling, being funny, drawing, learning, inventing, innovating, imagining things, etc. Of course I struggle to even get acceptable results because my brain is locked in on my biological specialty. Meanwhile others easily do 100x as much as me, and at a level that seems almost faultless from my point of view. They are optimized for those tasks, but I am not, so my ability to do them is blocked so not to get in the way of what I'm biologically primed to do, while theirs is continually strengthened. Indeed, I actually get worse as time goes on, as my development pushes me more towards my biological function and discards everything else as unnecessary.

It's time to stop pretending anyone can do anything and accept that genes and luck play a major role in our lives. Genes even determine up to 80% of how happy you are. Which also makes sense, because some tasks (ie fighting) are better when a person is angry or unhappy. Others are best when the person is happy. As a social animal, your genes don't give a flying fuck about you, they only care about the tribe, and you only matter as far as you will benefit it. It's literally fucking communism. You don't matter or have any say in your life, only the mythological "collective" matters as far as your biology is concerned. This world is a total crap shot.

The truth hurts. Keep taking blue pills if you want, actually I'd advise you to since it's the only way to cope with all this bullshit that is reality. But unfortunately they stopped working on me.
